titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV. Saturday Sun rose, clear.Fahrenheit

A day of the highest summer temperature from the rising to the setting Sun—confining me almost entirely to the house. Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks came out from Boston, and dined with us— They have recently returned from a tour of nearly three years in Europe— Mrs Foster, Mrs Angier, and Elizabeth Adams were here this afternoon— I answered a Letter from William Foster; and abridged much of what I am to deliver on the 4th. and not yet enough— My voice fails me from day to day— This Evening was warm like a Summer evening at Washington, with swarms of Mosquito’s— And there was an unusually brilliant Northern light.
2. IV.15. Sunday.

Heard Dr. Frothingham—in the morning from Zechariah 5.2 [“]And he said unto me, what seest thou? And I answered I see a flying roll:”—and in the afternoon from Luke 5.5. [“]Nevertheless, at thy word I will let down the net.” Both admirable discourses.— Dr. Frothingham and his Son, and Mr Lunt dined with us— I read the 3d. Sermon of the 10th. Volume of Saurin, upon the sublimity of the knowledge required of Christians. Evening visit from Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf— Abridged my Oration for the 4th. about one half.
3. IV: Monday.

At ten O’Clock this morning I left home with my Son Charles and rode with him to Boston in his chaise— At half past one there came to his Office in Court-Street a Stage and four horses in which we went without other passenger to Newbury-Port, through Salem and Ipswich— Charles had engaged for us two Seats in the ordinary Stage, but the Committee of Arrangements for the Inhabitants of Newbury-Port had given orders for this extra Stage to take us by ourselves— Reaching Ipswich just after four O’Clock we found there Mr Caleb Cushing, with Mr De Ford and Mr Bradbury, members of the Committee of Arrangements, in readiness with a Coach and four to take me on the remnant of the way— Mr Cushing gave me a notice that we should meet an escort in Newbury old town, and be accompanied by a procession thence to Newbury-Port— This accordingly happened— We alighted at Newbury old town where were assembled a numerous company of old and young persons and a cavalcade of young men for an escort— Mr De Ford, the Chairman of the Committee of arrangements here made a short address to me which I answered; after which preceded by the cavalcade we went on in procession to Mr Cushing’s House at Newbury-Port—
4. V. Tuesday.

I delivered an Oration before the inhabitants of the town of Newbury-Port, at their request on the anniversary of our National Independence.— From the time of my arrival in the town last evening, Chaos is the only word to express what I have seen and felt.— Mr Cushing lives with his father and mother, but they did not make their appearance— His Sister did the honours of the tea and breakfast table— Mr Wilde, a son of judge Wilde of the Supreme Court of the State, with his wife and son five or six years old, and Mrs Doane, a daughter of judge Wilde’s, came in from Boston last Evening and lodge here— Mr Cushing is a widower without children, and his wife was a daughter of judge Wilde— The firing of guns began at Midnight, and continued all night, to-gether with squibs and Crackers almost without intermission— At 9 this morning Coll. Coleman came and took me in a Chaise down into Water Street—where I found Mr Cushing standing upon a Platform and delivering an address to the eminent members of the fire department, drawn up in a line in front of him— He very soon concluded, and descending from the Platform—introduced me to them— Walked in procession with them; to a building belonging to them; where there was a table served with a cold collation.— I gave them a toast in lemonade. The fire department of Newbury-Port—always prepared for duty, may they never be needed to perform it— I then returned to Mr Cushing’s and shortly after proceeded to join the procession formed in high Street— I walked between Mr. Thomas B. Fox—Colleague of Dr John Andrews, the Minister of the first Congregational Church, and Mr Robert Cross, the reader of the Declaration of Independence— The procession was very large, and with it were several hundreds of children of the Public Schools, male and female— The march and countermarch, traversing many of the Streets of the town, took a long hour— The meeting house is some way westward of the market square, where it was when I resided at Newbury-Port. It was crowded with auditors as full as it could hold—hundreds could not obtain admission— There was music instrumental
and vocal—4. Stanza’s of R. T. Paine’s Song of Adams and Liberty were sung— Prayer, by Revd. Thomas B. Fox. Then an Anthem—next The Declaration of Independence was read by Mr Robert Cross of Amesbury— The 194th. Hymn of Dr. Belknap’s collection. O’er mountain-tops, the mount of God— In Latter days shall rise— This was performed at my request, and immediately preceded the delivery of my Oration which occupied an hour and a half—listened to with deep attention and occasional applause— The Hallelujah Chorus Anthem Chorus, and the Benediction Chorus closed the performances at half past two O’Clock—as I descended the pulpit in a small room adjoining the Church an old Lady came to me and shook hands with me saying she was now satisfied that I was a Christian, of which she had entertained doubts— I then returned to Mr Cushings house and dined, with a company of 12 gentlemen, entertained by Mr Cushing, consisting of the members of the Committee of Arrangements— Mr. Fox the officiating Clergymen, and others among whom a Mr Stearns. From 4 to 7. in the afternoon there came a numerous succession of visitors whom Mr Cushing introduced to me— Among them was Mr Morse the Minister of the Episcopal-church here, who married the widow of Dudley Atkins Tyng; his second wife; Sister of the first, and both daughters of Stephen Higginson of Boston—also Mr Edward Adams, now a member of the Senate of the Commonwealth from the County of Essex, who made some genealogical enquiries— Afterwards the Revd. Dr. Andrews came and sat about an hour with me— His wife, whom I saw when I passed through the town in September 1833. died about two Months since; and in his professional labours he is superseded by his Colleague, Mr Fox— Dr. Andrews reminded me that I had first introduced him as a preacher at Newbury-Port, and travelled with him from judge Dana’s house at Cambridge.— About 9. in the Evening I went to the Soiree, or party at the town Hall where a number of Ladies and Gentlemen were introduced to me.— I took a seat between two young women—one of whom asked me, if I knew Mr William Bartlett, I said yes, surely. She said he is my grandfather and in his 90th. year— Closed the Evening by going with Mr Cushing and Mr De Ford on the Mall where there were Fireworks— Passed by T. Parsons’s house— The Office taken away.
5. V:30. Wednesday— Return— Boston— Quincy.

Quiet Night’s rest— Mr Caleb Cushing’s father is an old Sea Captain and told me he was one of those who wintered at Cronstadt in 1809. and on returning in the Summer of 1810. was captured by Danish privateers, for sailing under an English convoy— Yesterday a Captain Stone spoke to me, who was master of one of the American Vessels that we found at Christiansand in September 1809. He said he was commander of the boat in which we were rowed up from the Ship Horace to Mr Isaacson’s— This morning a Mr Smith from Dover, New-Hampshire, came, and sat with me half an hour— He said he had removed from Newbury-Port to Dover in January 1787. and had ever since lived at Dover— He came now merely from curiosity to see me— Mr De Ford called twice and spoke about the printing of my Oration yesterday delivered and of which he said they should request a copy for the press— But as I might perhaps wish to take a copyright of it, they thought of leaving the printing to be done by my own direction— I said that if the inhabitants of that town felt any interest in having it printed here, I should conform entirely to their wishes; but otherwise I should be glad to have it done, under my immediate revision That I had never taken out a copyright, for any discourse delivered in public, and should take none now— But should only bespeak a number of copies to give away— Mr Cushing asked me also to write out for the press my answer to the address of Mr De Ford, on the green at Newbury; as his address had been requested for publication— After Breakfast, we took leave of Mr Cushing, and at a quarter before nine left Newbury-Port, my Son and myself in an extra Stage and four horses provided by the Committee of arrangements, and in which we returned through Ipswich Beverley, and Salem to Boston, where crossing in the Winisimet Steam ferryboat we arrived just after One P.M— We dined at the Revd: Dr Frothingham’s, and immediately after dinner returned, in Charles’s Chaise to Quincy— We reached home shortly after 5. P.M. with the grateful feeling on my part, of having passed through another fiery ordeal unscathed. [symbols]
6. V. Thursday.— Squantum dinner party.

Dissipation and Lassitude follow after the excitement and tension as those of the last three days— My time slips away unimproved, and I find nothing but disappointment in my plantations— Mr Lewis Kinney of Wareham brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr William Bates, and had some enquiries to make concerning the new Patent Law of 4. July 1836.— He has a patent as assignee, the specification of which claims more than he is entitled to— It has already run between 8 and 9 years—and he wished to surrender it and take out another patent with a specification claiming only so much of the invention as he was entitled to— I read to him the 13th. Section, of the new Patent Law of 4. July 1836. which was exactly the information that I wanted— He offered me compensation which I declined; but told him I should be glad to render him any service at the Patent Office, in my power during the next Session of Congress— Mr Bates’s Letter contains also questions relating to the claim of Tillson Burrows, which I am to answer.— Mr Minott Thayer came and introduced Mr Stoddard the town-Clerk and Treasurer of Braintree; who had a circular Letter from Mr William Lincoln, appointed by Governor Everett under an act of the Legislature of the Commonwealth to collect historical documents of the towns in the State— Mr Stoddard was enquiring for records of the town of Braintree; and Mr Thayer for Memorials of the family of his name— I shewed them my copy of the first volume of the Braintree Records; and the printed Family Memorial of Elisha Thayer of Dedham— Minott was not satisfied with this work, and said it contained many errors— This day was the annual meeting of the proprietors of Neponset Bridge, for the choice of a Secretary, Treasurer, Superintendent and directors— I rode with Charles to Squantum— The Officers of the last year were all rechosen— There was a petition of sundry persons at Dorchester for free passage of the Bridge on Sundays to attend public worship— Resolution passed accordingly— President Quincy, Dr Frothingham, Mr Lunt, Mr Wayles and his two Sons were at the dinner— We came home between 5 and 6. P.M. Louisa C. Smith left us.
7. IV. Friday.

Midshipman John Q. Adams was here this morning, returned from an excursion on horseback with his cousin William Foster to the Winipiseegee lake in New-Hampshire. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I spent the day in dissipation— Visited my garden, nursery and seminary, and found nothing but disappointment— I have received a Letter from Mr Robert Gilmor of Baltimore, consulting me concerning the inscriptions for a monument to Washington, erected by the State of Maryland—the funds raised by Lottery— I answered this Letter and proposed an abridgement of about two thirds of the words in almost every one of their inscriptions— Coll. and Mrs Quincy paid us an evening visit.
8. IV:15. Saturday.

Mr Brooks and Governor Everett came out from Boston, and were here at noon— Walked with us over to Charles’s house, the plastering of which is just finished. We had visits also from Isaac P. Davis with Bernard Henry; heretofore Consul of the United States at Gibraltar; and of Mr John Welles with Mr. Abbott Lawrence— At one Mr Brooks went in Charles’s Chaise to Coll Quincy’s to attend the meeting of the Trustees of the Agricultural Society— I went with Governor Everett and my Son Charles to the dinner at 3. The company besides Charles and myself were P. C. Brooks, Henry Codman, I. P. Davis, E. Everett,Finney, a new member of the agricultural board, John Heard, Bernard Henry, John C. Gray, Benjamin Guild—Abbott Lawrence, President Josiah Quincy, his Son Josiah—the host, John Welles, and Thomas L Winthrop, the President of the board— Mr Lawrence told me, that he was coming with Mrs Lawrence to pay us a visit, and wished to consult with me about petitioning against the annexation of Texas to the Union, and about the currency— Much conversation with John Welles concerning the by-gone days— Walked with Charles home— Mary was seized last Night with a violent attack of Cholera Morbus; and Dr Woodward was called to attend her about day-light this morning— Charles and his wife and Mary had spent the last Evening at Mr Beale’s.

9. IV:15. Sunday— Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Matthew 17.1. [“]And after six days, Jesus taketh Peter, James and John his brother, and bringeth them up into an high mountain apart. 2. And was transfigured before them: and his face did shine as the Sun, and his raiment was white as the light.” And in the afternoon from John 7.46. “The Officers answered, never man spake like this man.” Both these Sermons were discourses were panegyrical upon the character, and life of Jesus Christ That of the afternoon was most pleasing to me— The transfiguration was a miracle the necessity for which is not explained—a separate and sacred preternatural manifestation of Christ to three of the Apostles merely as would seem for their personal satisfaction. The afternoon Sermon shewing how the conduct and sayings of Jesus were superior to those of the rest of mankind was very impressive and affecting. I read the 4th. Sermon of the 10th. Volume of Saurin, upon the different methods of different preachers.
10. IV:15. Monday.

Charles and his wife went early this morning to Boston, and Charles to Cambridge as a member of a Committee appointed by the Overseers of the University to examine the Freshman Class in Greek— Mr Price Greenleaf came and viewed my seedling plants and advised me respecting the treatment of some of them; how to save them— I planted a dozen of mazzard cherry stones, the fruit just taken from the tree— Mr Lunt paid us a visit, and Mr J. A. Green came with Mr Newcomb—for a subscription to print the address of the Revd. Charles Brooks to the children of the Schools here on the 4th. of July— I told him he might put down my name for 50 Copies; but I did not wish to take a lead in the undertaking; having heard, that a part of Mr Brooks’s address was complimentary to myself— Charles and his wife came home about 6. O’Clock P.M— I scarcely know how it happened, but I wasted great part of the day in idleness, and no small part of it in sleep—
11. V Tuesday— My birth day— 70.

I am this day three score and ten years of age— I have lived the life of man, and from this day forth date the supplement to my life—praying the author of all good, that the remnant of my days may be employed in purposes of usefulness to my fellow creatures, and favoured with the divine blessing— Benjamin Bass came and paid me the debt which he has owed me since July 1829. with the years of interest due upon it— I returned him his note, and discharged his mortgage—returned him also his policy— Mr Fuller, and Mr Johnson agents of the American Anti-slavery Society were here, and applied in behalf of Mr Isaac Knapp, for the printing of my Oration delivered last week at Newbury-Port, which, I told them he should have, if the Committee of Arrangements at Newbury-Port would consent— They enquired also for the numbers of the Quincy Patriot containing my Addresses to the abolition petitioners, and to the inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, before that of the 3d. of March last—for which I referred them to Mr Green— Doctor and Mrs. Frothingham dined with us— I received a Letter from the Committee of arrangements at Newbury-Port, requesting a copy of my Oration for publication.
12 IV:15 Wednesday.

Mr Moses Grant called upon me this afternoon; and gave me two pamphlets from the Council of the Massachusetts Temperance Society; one being the 25th. report of the Council presented at their annual meeting on the 26th. of May last; and the other, Dr. William Ellery Channing’s Address on Temperance delivered at the Odeon, on the 28th. of February last— The direction to me, of the copy of Dr Channing’s address, is dated yesterday. I suppose purposely to remind me of my birth day— I answered the Letter from the Committee of arrangements at Newbury-Port, wrote out the substance of my answer to Mr De Ford’s Address, on the green at Newbury; and a separate Letter to Mr De Ford, to whom I enclosed the whole— Charles went to Boston and Cambridge to examine the Sophomores in Greek. Mr Beale and his daughter Caroline were here this eve.
13. IV:15. Thursday

I answered a Letter from the Revd. J. Edwards, President of the theological seminary at Andover, and wrote to Mr Lewis Johnson at Washington to enclose a Letter to him from John Otis of West-Barnstable brother of the late William Otis and Administrator of his Estate— Mrs T. Greenleaf and her daughter Mary Ann were here— Mary and Charles’s wife spent the afternoon and Evening at Coll. Quincy’s and Charles went to escort them home. I trimmed several young stocks of Apple trees in the Orchard North of the House, to prepare them for budding, and planted several cherry-stones at the West-end of the garden; near the transplanted red maple.— I was about to saw off the stock of the honey locust tree which I have thought winter killed, when I discovered that it was putting forth numerous shoots— Covered the wounds of several trees with the composition.
14. V. Friday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Midshipman John Q was here this morning.— Elizabeth dined here— Mr Charles A Davis and Sidney Brooks came out from Boston and dined with us— Much concerned at the accounts from England of the failure of the houses of Wilde, Wiggin and Wilson, and 150 others— Mr Davis told me that the interdiction by the Legislature of New-York to the Banks to declare any dividend while their suspension of specie payments shall continue, was his thunder— Charles mentioned to me a conversation he had this morning with Mr Whitcomb, the clerk in the Office of the 2d. Auditor Albion K. Parris— Mary and Charles’s wife rode this afternoon, with Miss Mary Ann Greenleaf and went and took tea at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I had Louisa-Catherine’s garden spot cleared out, and filled with fresh earth. The honey-locust tree in the garden is safe for this time, and is rapidly putting forth leaves— Sprinkling of a thunder shower.
15. IV:15. Saturday— Sun rose— 4:35.

Morning of intense, summer heat— Copious thunder shower towards sunset, and cool evening.— Mary and Charles’s wife went with Elizabeth C. and the midshipman John Q. Adams to Weymouth and took tea with Mrs Tufts—the children had an afternoon party at Mrs Lunt’s— I answered a Letter from P. S. DuPonceau, at Philadelphia; and one fromSparrow, President of the Philomathesian Society of Kenyon College at Gambier, Ohio; of which Society, I have been elected an honorary member.— I wrote also a short Letter to N. Frye at Washington— Planted in Pot 21 three ripe strawberries from the seedling vines at the seminary gate. The plants were all suffering by the drought.
16. IV:10 Sunday— Sun rose 4:36.

Heard Mr Phipps of Cohasset a son of the late Dr. Phipps of this town— His morning Sermon was from Psalm 55.19.— [“]Because they have no changes, therefore they fear not God”— I had heard a Sermon from this remarkable text by Mr Farley, on the 28th. of last May. How came this two young men, to select the same text? Was it an exercise, at the divinity school? Mr Phipps dined with us— And Louisa C. Smith— The afternoon Sermon was from John 12.42. “Nevertheless, among the chief rulers also, many believed on him; but because of the pharisees, they did not confess him, lest they should be put out of the synagogue 43. For they loved the praise of men, more than the praise of God.” Both Mr Phipps’s Sermons were very short; and were written and delivered in a temperate manner.— I read the 5th. Sermon of the 10th. volume of Saurin— On a prayer of St. Paul for the Ephesians—the text being from Ephesians 1.16.17.18.19. Mr De grand came out from Boston and spent the Evening with us— After tea, I walked with him to my Son’s house, and viewed the variegated beautiful prospect from it— Saw the Sun set from a Northern chamber window at 7.24. The moon rose immediately after the Sun had set— A beautiful Summer’s day after the rain of last Evening.
17. IV. Monday.— Bath and swim

I went to Charles’s house to see the Sun rise; but it had risen in a haze. The day was clear and cloudless. I answered a Letter from Dr Phelps, and received one from Mr De Ford at Newbury Port.— The People of the Town prefer to have the Oration printed there— John Q. Adams the Midshipman, with John and Edward Foster were here— With them, and with Charles, I took a bath and swim just before Noon at Daniel Greenleafs wharf, which made me drowsy for the remainder of the day— Walked up again as Evening came on to Charles’s House, and saw the Sun set from the Northern chamber window— Received from the Postmaster general Amos Kendall a pamphlet upon his refusal to obey a Mandamus from the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia; with an Opinion of the Attorney General, against the jurisdiction of the Court.
18. III.30. Tuesday.

I went over to Charles’s House and saw the Sunrise from his S. E corner window at 4:38. Mr Stoddard the town-Clerk and Treasurer of Braintree called to enquire if I had collected any information respecting the persons who were distinguished within the State, in the times immediately preceding the revolutionary War; but I had none. The day was clear from Morning till Night— The sun, blazing; but the atmosphere cooled with an Easterly wind, which returned in the Evening cold from the South-west. I despatched my answer to Dr Phelps and the manuscript of my Oration to Mr De Ford, at Newbury-Port— Began a Letter to N. Biddle, and from mere indolence did not finish it.— My plants are now many of them perishing by the heat of the Sun— Two of my Pear stocks in the garden budded by Price Greenleaf in 1832, bear fruit this year— One upon a stock that was in the hazel bushes and one between the centre alley and the road— Two small honey locusts are putting forth leaves, as well as the large one which I thought dead— My hickory trees and Oaks are thriving. Mr Beale was here and invited us to a party at Squantum next Thursday.
19. III.45. Wednesday

Saw the Sunrise again from the Southeast chamber window of Charles’s house; but it was covered with haze at the horizon, and about five minutes up when first visible. Alpheus Spear came and settled his quarter’s rent for the Mount Wollaston farm— I finished the Letter to N. Biddle, and wrote one to William T. Otto: to enclose with it an autograph Copy of a Letter from my father to Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson, dated Bath Hotel Westminster 20. June 1785— I read a very curious Sermon of Dr. William Sprague, of Albany upon the Tower of Babel— The confusion of which he thinks applicable to the Condition of the Presbyterian-Church in this Country, and to the condition of the Country itself— Bath and swim with Charles at one O’Clock P.M. at Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf.
20. IV:15. Thursday.— Squantum dinner party—

Charles and his wife, Mary and myself attended the dinner party at Squantum— The company besides consisted of Elizabeth C and Midshipman John Q. Adams—Mr Beale and his daughter Anne—a Miss Cushing,—John Foster son of Mrs Phineas, Thomas and Mrs Greenleaf and their daughter Mary Ann—Mr Lunt’s father and mother; his brother James with his wife and infant daughter, himself, Mrs Lunt and their daughter Anne—Edward and Mrs Miller and their daughter Hannah—Miss Pearson a sister of the older Mrs Lunt, Louisa C. Smith, Mr Wayles the son with his wife and Louisa Wayles, Mrs. Terry, and Dr Woodward—thirty-one in number— I went with Charles in his Chaise about one O’Clock— The tide had overflowed the beach— We had a poor Chowder—other fish, and rasberries and mazzard cherries for the only fresh fruit— Mr Lunt the father told me that he had been an inhabitant of Georgetown D.C from 1793 to 1801. The weather was fine, the temperature warm, the sky hazy, and the chief sight we saw was the cows swimming over from the island to the Squantum beach, and also swimming sheep— We came home about 6. in the afternoon— French began the clearing out of the ditch from the pond North of the House to the brook.
21. V. Friday

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Mr Whitney called to make enquiries, concerning the history of the house in which I now live; and that of the two houses in which I now live my father and I were born— I gave him all the information that I possess.— Of this house I knew little more than that the Eastern end of it, the long room, and the entry through the house was built by my father in 1798—that he came into the other part of it in June 1788 on his return from England—that it had been purchased for him by Dr Cotton Tufts the year before, from Leonard Vassal Borland whose deed I have. That it had been as part of Borland’s property forfeited in the Revolution—Borland having been a refugee—but the confiscation not having been legalized according to the Statute during the War, Borland recovered it after the Peace— My Grandfather John Adams was married 31 October 1734— My father was born 19/30 October 1735— I have a deed from my grandfathers father Joseph Adams to him of the land upon which the old house stands—dated 1731. acknowledged 1733. and recorded 1736— His will is dated in 1733. and he died in 1736. From all which I conclude that my Grandfather built the House in 1734. immediately before his marriage— He bought the other house with nine or ten Acres of land of John and Richard Billings of Boston in 1744. when, and by whom the house was built I do not know— Mr Whitney is collecting these historical incidents for publication— I walked to the Post-Office with Letters before dinner— French and Thomasfinished the clearing out of the ditch in the Orchard North of the House. The ladies went this evening to Mr Beale’s and he escorted them home— There was a bright Northern light.
22. IV:15 Saturday.

A wasted day— Much of the morning lost in strolling over the orchard back of the house. Most of the remainder in assorting Newspapers to find one containing the return of the census of the town of Quincy, the present year. In search also of an autograph Letter of my father to send to Virgil David—for when I once commence a search to ascertain a fact in a book or paper, it usually costs me a day. A man by the name of John Hayward is publishing a New-England Gazetteer, and
has written to me requesting me to furnish him an Article for the town of Quincy— I accordingly wrote a short article for him yesterday, and gave in it the population of the town, by the returns of the census in 1800. 1810. 1820 and 1830—but wanted that of 1837. which I had seen in a Newspaper, and thus was put upon the search which consumed so much of this day— Mr and Mrs. Sidney Brooks, Mrs Frothingham and Mrs Edward Everett from Boston, paid us an afternoon, and Elizabeth C. Adams, with John Quincy, Hannah Miller and John and Fanny Foster were here in the Evening— My garden, Nursery, and seminary seedlings are going through a fiery ordeal of drought— The Honey-Locusts have all revived, but all the black walnutts are dead or dying. The peach-trees look wretchedly; and very few of them bear at-all. The Philadelphia Maples grow most luxuriantly. N. 6. of the Seminary has a growth of three feet six inches already this Season.
23. IV:30 Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt, this morning from Ephesians 3.19.—that ye might be filled with all the fulness of God—and in the afternoon from Job 21.7. “Wherefore do the wicked live, become old, yea are mighty in power?” the text of the afternoon was one, from which a discourse of deep impression was to be expected; but it was not equal to many others of Mr Lunt— But the 6th. Sermon of the 10th. volume of Saurin from Acts 24. 25. the discourse of St. Paul to Felix and Drusilla made up for all other deficiencies. There is no other of the Sermons of Saurin superior if there is one equal to it— The duty of a Christian preacher, to reprove the vices of powerful men, is set forth in this discourse in all its glory, and all its dangers— The example of Paul, is of irresistible authority— He preached before Felix upon the very depravities of which Felix himself was guilty— Upon Justice, Temperance and Judgment to come— It is perhaps not possible for a modern preacher fully to imitate the example of Paul.— Saurin exhorts his brethren to do so; but does not so much practise it himself— Young Foster with John Quincy and Louisa C. Smith dined with us— Charles and I spent the Evening at Edward Miller’s—Coll. Josiah Quincy junr here.
24. IV. Monday

Mr Curtis was here this morning and we had conversation upon the concerns upon Mr Ward N. Boylston’s Will— There was a shuffling and knavish Letter from Petty Vaughan evading as usual the payment of balances which he acknowledges to be due from him.— There was also an opinion of Mr John Davis as a lawyer, upon bequests of Mr Boylston to the town of Princeton— The Town is also a Parish; and there is a question whether the Town or the Parish Officer are the Trustees which Mr Davis thinks should be settled by an amicable suit at Law— The grant is also upon Condition that the land shall not be taxed— A condition which Mr Davis thinks the donor had no right to prescribe, it being contrary to Law, and therefore that a breach of the condition will not operate a forfeiture of the grant. Mr Curtis proposes that a third account should be settled by the Executors before the judge of probate; and as the judge will hold his Court in Quincy a fortnight from to-morrow, Tuesday the 8th of August, I proposed to him to dine with me, and to invite Mrs Boylston also to dine here that day; to which he agreed— There are no recent advices respecting the Nova-Scotia Lands— I removed about two bushels of Stones from Plat 1. of the S.E. Seminary row, and spread some fresh earth over the ground to save a transplanted peach tree and seedling wild plumtree growing there— Just after dinner there was a shower with distant thunder; and another more copious in the Evening.— Our man Thomas working to clear out the ditch in the Orchard North of the house this afternoon ran a rusty nail an inch into his foot— A man by the name of Orin Fry died in this town last week of a lock-jaw, from a similar accident. We were therefore much alarmed, and Dr Stetson was sent for to Thomas Dr Woodward being confined at home with a fever— Dr Stetson thought Thomas’s wound with prudent treatment would not be dangerous. John H. Foster and Midshipman John Q. were here at the edge of the Evening, and went away just as the shower came on heavily— I answered a Letter from Charles A. Davis and wrote a short Letter to John Otis, at Barnstable, West, to enclose one to him from Lewis Johnson at Washington—
25. IV. Tuesday.

Cleared off the stones from the second plat of the southernmost seminary row of transplanted trees— There are in it four seedling pear trees one cherry and one pignut hickory of the present year French thinned off the front row of apple and pear seedlings of the present year— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine—brought the news of the death of the king of England William the 4th. on the 20th of June— E. Price Greenleaf came, and buddied for me five Applestocks in the Orchard. 3 Trowbridge, and two Bellefleur, and six Pear sucker stocks in the garden. 3 Bartlett, and 3 Harvard— Mr Peter Whitney, and his son Augustus Frederick were here. The son shewed me two engraved prints, one of this house, and one of the two houses at the foot of Penn’s hill in which my father and I were born; to be published in the next number of the American Magazine.—Mr Loring, and Miss Anna Thaxter of Hingham were next here— Mr Loring spoke to me of the Petition from Hingham presented at the last Session of Congress for an improvement of their harbour; where he wishes to have again called up at their next Session— And he invited me to visit Hingham, and view the spot where they wish the improvement to be made. And at the same time to go upon a fishing party— I agreed to go next Thursday week— Miss Thaxter told me her father was very feeble, and afflicted with a paralytic disorder—that she doubted whether he would survive the present year— Louisa C. Smith, and Elizabeth C. Adams were here this afternoon at tea and the midshipman John Q came for them in the Evening— I received a Letter from James Herring urging the performance of a promise I had made him for articles of biography of my father and mother. Received also a Letter from Morss and Brewster at Newbury-Port printers with a proof sheet of the Oration which I revised, and sent back corrected, with a Letter of which I kept no copy. The errors are numerous— They request that Mr Cushing may revise the remainder to which I have assented.
26. IV. Wednesday

Forty years from my wedding day. I dug up and cleared away the Stones, from the third plat of South seminary row— There are in it one transplanted dying black walnut six seedling Apple trees, two pears and one shagbark walnut all very unpromising— One fruit tree from the seed, upon each of these plats—is the extent of my undertaking; and to effect this I must limit my attention, chiefly to them.— I answered a second Letter from Mr Robert Gilmer of Baltimore upon the inscriptions for the Monument in honour of Washington. I answered also a Letter from Mr James Herring, and wrote further upon the biographical article concerning my mother— There was an evening tea party here, consisting of the families of Coll. Josiah Quincy junr, of Mrs T. B. Adams and Mr Edward Miller.— Mrs Nicholson wife of Mrs Edward Miller’s brother, of Plymouth was of the company— And Mrs John T. Apthorp, once Grace Foster when I visited at her father’s house at the Bottom of the Mall at Boston, on Sunday Evening’s from 1790 to 1793. She reminded me of those times, and I have seldom seen her since— I remember them well; and in reflecting upon what has befallen her and me since that time what a multitude of Scenes; joyous and melancholy crowd upon my memory. Her fate has been as checkered as mine— She was a twin sister—daughters of William Foster— Apthorp married first her sister Mary, who at an early age died in childbed, and then he married her— They have lost several children, all by consumptions, and just as they successively reached the age of maturity.— Mrs Josiah Quincy junr. did not come this Evening; finding herself indisposed. She is a woman of much intelligence, but infirm health and consequent irritability of temper; and eccentricity of deportment. There is less allowance made for the infirmities of such persons than I think should be extended to them— Mrs Quincy is no favourite any where, and has not always justice done her— I fear she has not a long career before her—
27. III:45. Thursday.— Boston and back to Quincy

Dug up and cleared away the Stones from the fourth South Seminary row plat.— It has on it, a central tall slender transplanted cherry tree, surrounded by at least forty stunted apple and pear seedlings, and two walnuts, not one of which promises to live— I went into Boston, in Gillet’s omnibus—a new and enlarged Stage Coach— Alighted at Charles’s Office—deposited the Letter to James Herring at the Post-Office, and purchased a Bible for a present to my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa. Called at the House of my old friend Joseph Hall, to visit him, but he was not at home— At Noon I attended the meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, and presented them copies of my Eulogies upon La Fayette, and upon James Madison— I gave also to Mr Thomas L. Winthrop as President of the American Antiquarian Society, copies of the same discourses, for them; and I promised a copy of each of them to Mr Winthrop himself.— Mr Savage enquired if I had received a Letter from him requesting a Letter of introduction, for Mr George Ticknor to Genl. Bernard— I had not received it but promised the Letter— At 1/2 past 12. I attended the meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University, in the Senate chamber, Governor Edward Everett presided— The Corporation presented the names of Alvan Lamson and Convers Francis, for Doctors of Divinity; the names of two Lawyers for Doctors of Laws, and one for an honorary degree of Master of Arts—the Meeting was adjourned to thebefore Commencement day— I walked home with Governor Everett, and sat conversing with him perhaps an hour— Mrs Everett came in the while— I called at the House where the Quincy stage stops and asked Gillett to call for me at Governor Winthrop’s which he promised if I should not be at 4. O’Clock at Charles’s Office. I dined at Mr Winthrop’s— Mr Sparks—Joseph Willard Secretary of the Historical Society Mr Felt and Dr Gamaliel Bradford there— Call at Charles’s Office. Gillett had been 5 minutes gone— Went back towards Governor Winthrop’s again and missed the omnibus again—overtook it by a hot stern chase—home at 6. P.M. Joshua Curtis of Abington here, with papers of a pension claim for Elizabeth Perry— Jeremiah Mason and Dr J. W. Warren here while I was absent—
28. III:45. Friday

Dug up and cleared out the stones from the 5th. Plat of South seminary row— There is on it a central nearly dead but reviving transplanted peach tree, surrounded by about 40 puny seedling apple-trees, 2 pears, and two Hickories— For a bushel basket full of stones removed, I had the vacuity filled up with mud from the partly drained pond in the Orchard— Charles and his wife went to a large family party of the Brooks’s at Medford, to pass the day and the night— The day was warm, and I was exhausted by the excursion and the bustling exercise of yesterday that I wasted this day in listless dissipation of Spirit— Coll. Quincy paid me an afternoon visit with Mr James P. Espy of Philadelphia who claims to have made a great discovery in meteorology— So great that he likens it to the Newtonian discovery of gravitation—reducing all the atmospheric phenomena of storms to one principle, by means of which he thinks the gravity, the continuance and the direction of Storms summer and winter may be calculated— Mr Espy has made many observations, but is in want of means to make many more, and the aid of Congress to provide the funds— He told me that Mr John Sergeant had promised to introduce the subject to the consideration of the House of Representatives, at the approaching Session, and I assured him that I should readily afford any assistance in my power to any proposition which Mr Sergeant might offer— The substance of the theory is that storms are conflicts of clouds driven in opposite directions from a circumference to a centre— Mr Josiah Adams junr was here, and gave me an estimate of the cost of materials for books he has in two chambers of the farm house, which Mr J. J. Carr is to quit next week. He is to remove into the house which he has built this Season, at the corner opposite our easternmost barn— And I propose to have shelves in two of the chambers, of the farm house to clear off the lumber of my library— There were two light thunder Showers, one about Sunset the other between 9 and 10 in the Evening. Copious rains— I sleep so little in the night that I am drowsy all day— Mr Quincy brought me a triennial catalogue of 1836.
29. III:30. Saturday.

Stone-stripped Plat 6. and for a heaped bushel basket full of stones, filled their place with Orchard Pond mud.— Enlarged the border of Fanny’s seedling bed, and filled the circumference with orchard Pond mud. Midshipman John Q. Adams and John H. Foster were here, and witnessed my Assignment of Pew N. 75 in the Stone meeting house to Job Faxon— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, and met there Harvey Field— I agreed to go next Tuesday Morning, if the weather proves fair to the ground which he cleared up last summer on Penn’s Hill; and he said he would pay me the balance due on his agreement with me for the wood— At the Office of the Quincy Patriot, I exchanged several numbers, so as to make my file compleat except the 4 numbers for January— On Wednesday last there was a Meeting at Dorchester, at which an Anti-Texas Convention of delegates from all the towns in the 12th. Congressional District, was proposed to be held at Quincy, before the meeting of Congress—and a Resolution was adopted; inviting me to attend the meeting— Joseph Richards of Braintree John A. Green of Quincy and H. W. Blanchard of Dorchester were appointed a Committee to designate the day and hour for the Convention— Mr Green consulted me about the day—wishing to give as long a notice as might conveniently be given; and I advised Wednesday the 23d. or Thursday the 24th. of August— My next call was upon Mr L. Brackett, who took the acknowledgment of my assignment of pew N. 75. to Job Faxon, and of my discharge upon the mortgage of Benjamin Bass. I returned the mortgage to Mr Bass, and he took back a 3. dollar Bill of the Franklin Bank, which he had given me with other bills in payment of his note— He now exchanged it for a good bill— Those of the Franklin bank do not pass at-all— Charles and his wife returned from Medford, before dinner— I received this morning from Alexander H. Everett a Norfolk Argus extra, containing his Speech at the Meeting on Bunker-hill, on the 4th. of this month, which I read, not without mortification— This meeting was gotten up at the instigation of Amos Kendall the Postmaster General to pass anti-bank resolutions, and sustain the present administration— A. H. Everett has passed from one extreme of party devotion to another extreme of the opposite party, and his character is between the upper and the nether Millstone.
30. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt, this morning from 2. Corinthians 10.12—but they, measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves with among themselves are not wise— The doctrines was that wisdom consists in assuming for measurement and comparison out of ourselves, and that for the true Christian, the standard is Jesus Christ himself—or in other words, that religion is the standard— This position was maintained with great power, and with great variety of illustration— In the afternoon the Sermon was from Romans 10.3. [“]For they, being ignorant of God’s righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves, unto the righteousness of God.” Too nearly the same subject as that of the morning— The righteousness recommended was that of Faith— Mr Lunt gave notice that the Communion would be administered next Sunday, and a collection taken up in the afternoon to form a parish library, for which contributions of books were also solicited— I read the 7th. Sermon of the 10th. Volume, upon the fast day of the 7th. of March 1714— There is something edifying in a fast day Sermon of a former age— Mr William Lee was here and introduced Mr Campbell of Alabama— John Quincy the Midshipman and his Sister Elizabeth and John H. Foster were also here, and after them President Quincy and his daughter Abby, and in the Evening Joseph H. Adams and Francis Foster, who had come out from Boston to dine. Joseph is now stationed at the Navy-Yard, at Charlestown— In the Evening, Mary and Charles’s wife went into visit at Mr Beale’s— His second daughter Frances, a beautiful girl of about 17. is perishing with a rapid consumption— Dr Jackson of Boston, was called to visit her last week in consultation with Dr Woodward, and pronounced her case desperate— My time for writing was all occupied by visitors.
31. IV. Monday.

Stone-strip’d Plat 7.— There were on it, one central transplanted cherry-tree; dead with the exception of 3. sides shoots 12 Apple-seedlings. 4 pears. 2. Oaks, one wild cherry and 1. grapevine— About half of which I uprooted in clearing off four bushel baskets full of stones— The vacant space was filled with the soil from the orchard pond; but it took me more than half the day—and of course diverted me from all literary occupation. I wrote short answers to Letters of enquiry from Revd. Joseph Tuckerman and Benjamin Dodge, but the day was wofully wasted. Mrs Edward Miller with her daughter, Mrs Nicholson, and Miss Mansfield were here to visit the Ladies— A Heavy shower of rain just before dinner— Sent over several trunks of books and papers to the farm house which has been evacuated by Mr John J. Carr— He has removed into his own new house.— The seminary Philadelphia Maple has grown 4 feet 2 inches this season, and is now 7 feet 10 inches high.

Day. I rise usually between 4 and 5. sometimes between 3 and 4—wash and water my pot seedling trees, and visit the Seminary seedlings— I have now so many of these, that they almost engross all my attention— The seminary seedlings of the present year are so puny and miserable, that I have undertaken to improve the soil in which they grow— I have for the last week worked between 2 and 3 hours every morning in unstoning the eight plats opened last Summer for fruits trees— This employs me till breakfast time about 8. O’Clock— Then wandering about my garden nursery and Orchard—reading Newspapers and Letters received by the mail till between 2 and 3. p.m—dine— Charles goes about three times a week to Boston, and returns before dinner— After dinner I have from two to three hours of drowsiness, and slumbering— Then write about an hour; journalizing or writing Letters.— Sun sets now 12 minutes after 7. spent walking in the porch South of the House, and in conversation with my family— The children go to bed about 8 P.M— We, about 10.
